title: Erdős Problem #166: Ramsey Number R(4,k) Lower Bound
description: Prove that R(4,k) >> k³/(log k)^O(1). SOLVED by Mattheus-Verstraete (2023): R(4,k) >> k³/(log k)⁴, earning the $250 Erdős prize.

meta.author: Erdős, Spencer, Ajtai, Komlós, Szemerédi, Mattheus, Verstraete

overview.historicalContext: Erdős offered $250 for proving that R(4,k) grows like k³ up to polylogarithmic factors. For 43 years (1980-2023), the gap between Spencer's lower bound (k log k)^{5/2} and the Ajtai-Komlós-Szemerédi upper bound k³/(log k)² remained open. This was finally resolved by Mattheus and Verstraete in 2023 using algebraic constructions from finite geometry.
overview.problemStatement: Prove that R(4,k) >> k³/(log k)^O(1), where R(4,k) is the Ramsey number representing the minimum N such that any 2-coloring of K_N contains either a monochromatic K_4 or a monochromatic K_k.
overview.proofStrategy: The formalization defines Ramsey numbers R(s,t) as the minimum N guaranteeing monochromatic cliques in 2-colorings. We prove basic properties (symmetry, R(1,t)=1, R(2,t)=t) and state the historical bounds. The main result follows from the Mattheus-Verstraete theorem establishing R(4,k) ≥ c·k³/(log k)⁴.
keyInsights: Ramsey numbers R(4,k) grow like k³ up to polylogarithmic factors
Algebraic constructions from finite geometry broke the 43-year barrier
Current bounds: c·k³/(log k)⁴ ≤ R(4,k) ≤ C·k³/(log k)²
Probabilistic methods alone could not achieve the k³ lower bound
The remaining gap is only in the exponent of log k (4 vs 2)

sections.title: Ramsey Number Definitions
sections.summary: Defines Ramsey numbers R(s,t) as the minimum N guaranteeing monochromatic cliques in any 2-coloring of K_N.

sections.title: Basic Properties
sections.summary: Proves fundamental properties: R(s,t) is symmetric, R(1,t) = 1, and R(2,t) = t.

sections.title: Known Exact Values
sections.summary: States known exact values R(3,3)=6, R(4,4)=18, R(4,5)=25 and bounds for R(3,k).

sections.title: Historical Lower Bounds
sections.summary: Spencer's 1977 lower bound R(4,k) >> (k log k)^{5/2} using probabilistic methods.

sections.title: Upper Bound (AKS)
sections.summary: Ajtai-Komlós-Szemerédi 1980 upper bound R(4,k) << k³/(log k)² using greedy coloring.

sections.title: The Solution (2023)
sections.summary: Mattheus-Verstraete breakthrough: R(4,k) >> k³/(log k)⁴ using finite geometry constructions.

sections.title: Main Theorem (SOLVED)
sections.summary: Formalizes and proves Erdős Problem #166 is solved, establishing current best bounds.

sections.title: Summary and Status
sections.summary: Complete summary stating the problem was solved by Mattheus-Verstraete in 2023 with the $250 prize.

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #166 was SOLVED by Mattheus and Verstraete in 2023, earning the $250 Erdős prize. The answer is YES: R(4,k) ≥ c·k³/(log k)⁴ for some constant c > 0. This breakthrough used algebraic graph constructions from finite geometry, achieving bounds that 43 years of probabilistic methods could not reach.
conclusion.implications: The solution demonstrates the power of algebraic constructions in Ramsey theory. The technique of using incidence graphs of projective planes provides a new paradigm for constructing extremal graphs, potentially applicable to other Ramsey-type problems.
openQuestions: What is the exact exponent of log k in the optimal lower bound?
Can the techniques extend to R(s,k) for s ≥ 5?
Are there fully explicit (deterministic) constructions matching these bounds?
What is the behavior of multicolor Ramsey numbers R(4,4,...,k)?
